metadata.case_name: Santosh Kumar and Northern General Agencies v. Plaintiff

facts.text: Defendants drew a cheque for Rs. 60,000 in favour of the plaintiff which was dishonoured on presentation to the Bank.
Plaintiff filed suit under Order XXXVII CPC in Court of Commercial Subordinate Judge, Delhi, Suit No. 264 of 1956.
Defendants applied for leave to defend under r.3 of Order XXXVII.
Trial Judge held defence raises triable issue but defendants placed nothing to show bona fide defence; granted conditional leave requiring security for suit amount and costs.
Defendants applied for review before trial court and failed.
Defendants applied under Art. 227 Constitution to Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Misc. No. 896-D of 1956 and failed.
Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136.

Defendants admitted execution of cheque but pleaded it was given as collateral security for price of goods supplied by plaintiff; goods paid for by cash payments and other cheques, so cheque served its end; set out exact dates and cheque numbers.

legal_issues.text: Whether the trial court could impose conditions for leave to defend under Order XXXVII r.3 despite finding a triable issue, without evidence of non-bona fide defence.
Scope of discretion under Order XXXVII r.3(2) to impose terms like security, and when unconditional leave must be granted upon triable issue.

petitioner_arguments.text: Defence raises triable issue as admitted by trial judge; no basis to impose conditions without proof of non-bona fide; defence supported by affidavit with specific dates and cheque numbers.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Order XXXVII r.3(1); principles from Jacobs v. Booths Distillery Company; triable issue test

respondent_arguments.text: Discretion under r.3(2) is unfettered; no appeal lies unless grave miscarriage of justice; trial judge exercised discretion properly.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: D.N. Banerji v. P.R. Mukherjee; Waryam Singh v. Amarnath; Gopala Rao v. Subba Rao

court_reasoning.text: Procedural laws facilitate justice, not penal; interpret with elasticity and natural justice principles; defendant not to be condemned unheard.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Laws of procedure grounded on natural justice; must construe to avoid frustrating justice.

court_reasoning.text: Order XXXVII r.3(1) mandates leave if affidavit discloses facts requiring proof of consideration or sufficient facts; r.3(2) allows conditions but discretion judicial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If triable issue, leave unconditional; conditions only if non-bona fide to prevent prolongation.

court_reasoning.text: Trial judge erred: defence clear and precise on affidavit; no need for documents at leave stage; proof comes after leave granted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defence not vague; raises real issue if proved.

court_reasoning.text: Interference warranted if discretion arbitrary or misunderstands principles, causing failure of justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Obvious failure of justice if judgment against defendant who would succeed if allowed to prove case.

holdings.text: Where defence raises triable issue, leave to defend must be granted unconditionally; conditions only if defence sham or to ensure speedy trial upon non-bona fide suspicion.
Court cannot deem defence non-bona fide arbitrarily or for lack of proof before leave stage; must apply judicial rules.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of High Court and trial judge set aside; case remanded to trial court for trial of issues raised by defendants.
outcome.relief_granted: Unconditional leave to defend implied; remand for full trial

key_quotes.text: A code of procedure must be regarded as such. It is procedure, something designed to facilitate justice and further its ends not a penal enactment for punishment and penalties.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle for interpreting procedural laws like Order XXXVII

key_quotes.text: Our laws of procedure are grounded on a principle of natural justice which requires that men should not be condemned unheard.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies mandatory unconditional leave on triable issue

key_quotes.text: Whenever the defence raises a triable issue, leave must be given, and later cases say that when that is the case it must be given unconditionally.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States the binding rule from precedents

key_quotes.text: The test is to see whether the defence raises a real issue and not a sham one.
key_quotes.speaker: court
